"Still, Yahoo has gravely serious problems. It needs to pivot to one or two industry-changing directions and products ... "

You don't create industry-changing "pivots" with 8000 people in an auditorium brainstorming session. You create the pivots in teams of ten or fewer people, maybe a few hundred people of various disciplines all-told throughout the company. The other 7000 people work in collaborative teams implementing the MANAGEMENT-COMMUNICATED MESSAGE. That work is not 100% face-to-face - cubicles are bad, but bullpens are worse.

When one chooses not to work from home it doesn't mean one has chosen to not THINK of work. One who is FORCED to work only at the office may well choose to not think about work unless at the office.

Weakly considered dictum, the sign of an epic fail in the offing.....

I don't begrudge her a C-suite nursery but did she also set up planning committees to create several at-office nursery-preschools?

She found baby "...way easier?" So, Ms. Mayer is not up in the middle of the night warming a bottle and rocking her child back to sleep. Perhaps her husband or a nanny does. Likely she has domestic help most employed mothers don't and can't afford. She might remember that enough money makes many aspects of life "way easier." Is she pondering whether her employees have access to that aspect of "way easier?" Creativity, which Yahoo desperately needs, doesn't flourish amidst angry turmoil.

Still, Yahoo has gravely serious problems. It needs to pivot to one or two industry-changing directions and products ... but ... first must to visualize, prioritize, prototype, test, and release those products. Before that, brainstorming and assessing themselves are needed. That means, at least for a while, get all the faces together and talking to each other. Either successfully pivot now, or start an office pool guessing when the company will pass from the scene.

Ms. Mayer has said her priorities are God, family, and Yahoo. She's provided high-profile refuge for her family. Will she nurture that at Yahoo for her Yahoos? Her results at this late date may depend on creating a refuge from family stresses to minimize workaholic guilt and effects.

Academic freedom is both more and less restrictive than general freedom of speech, as Fish notes.

More restrictive, since only academics--typically PhD's have earned it--as licensed experts in their fields. Non-experts owe due respect; not obedience or silence, but deference. General freedom of speech allows any fool to spout off about anything--hardly deserving deference.

Less restrictive, since the license, and other filters, entitle academics to access information, pursue research--and often funding--denied those without the degree of learning. And to publicize--in print and in class--the results--subject only to due academic process--the rules of order.

Academic discourse is essentially dialectical--the exposition/interpretation of ideas--logical critique--better idea--on and on.

The unqualified are out of order--usually guilty of bad-discrimination: letting irrelevant factors count or not counting all the relevant ones--due to ignorance, prejudice (pre-judgment), partiality (counting only part; or being pre-allied to a party) , bias (a bad point of view--perceptual or conceptual), or conflict of interest.

As in the professorially based professions--medicine, law, engineering, architecture etc.--only fools think paying the piper entitles them to call the tune.

The, experts, the connoisseurs, the discriminating, often have a trained eye, ear, nose, tongue or finger allowing notice of both forests and trees--lost on the untrained.

The spending cuts pose a significant political threat to the Republican/Tea Party, more so than to Democrats. Although many Republican/Tea Party members are standing firm, insisting that their party will be fine if the cuts go through, there are many reasons for the party to see the dangers that lay ahead.

The cuts could push congressional politics in a liberal direction and establish the foundation for solid Democratic gains in 2014.

The danger for the Republican/Tea Party is that the budget cuts will severely weaken public support for the austerity theme that the party has been promoting since 2010. The cuts will make "deficit reduction" something very real to average American citizens and business and something that is often quite painful rather than an abstract debate over numbers.

While Americans have historically been hostile to government, they tend to support specific government services when asked by pollsters. So the federal government's overall spending might not be popular as a concept, but Social Security and Medicare are.

The spending cuts will shift the debate toward the specifics. Americans will watch as government services are retrenched. The last time this happened, things didn't go well for the Republicans.

When the federal government shut down in 1995-1996 because of a budget standoff between Republicans and President Clinton, the Republicans faced a huge backlash when Americans were unable to access basic government services.

"That is pure speculation."

It's speculation with a grounding in truth: There were numerous serious slave rebellions in slaveholding states. The leadership varied, the ideology varied, the goals varied, but the slaves kept on trying. There's a decent chance they could have won eventually.

Also quite relevant: In some of the rebellions, the slaves were joined or aided by poor white people who had decided that they had more in common with the slaves than they did with the slaveholders. Howard Zinn and others have argued that racism was stoked by large plantation owners so that poor whites would stay away from rebellious or escaping slaves.

The slave rebellions in the South were never that serious.  Nat Turner's, for example, lasted all of two days and killed about five dozen whites, and that was one of the most serious slave rebellions.  The one in Louisiana in 1811 also only lasted a few days and only saw a few hundred slaves rebel.  None of the slave rebellions lasted more than a few days.  If that's the best slaves could do, then there was nothing like a "decent chance" of success.

"Southerners would doubtless have imported more and more slaves until they were overwhelmed by their own bondsmen. "

That is pure speculation. When the southern states seceded in 1860, slaves were only a majority in two of the eleven states, and then only a bare majority. In Haiti, the slaves outnumbered their white masters by a factor of 10-1. Even had such a rebellion been successful, there's no reason to believe that you still wouldn't have had 650,000 Americans die to end slavery; you just would've traded off slave lives for those of northern whites.

When looking at upper South states having fewer slaves because of the lack of a fugitive slave clause, the article overlooks 1) that there would be a national boundary rather than an interstate one, which could be more tightly sealed off and 2) that the new Northern states might not have wanted fleeing slaves. Illinois, for example, had a law barring blacks from the state.

One can also look at how the growth of the Old Northwest would've been impacted by having to cross a national boundary to go down the Mississippi.

We have yet to read or watch an interview with a panel of bona fide working poor or lower-middle-class Americans, to get THEIR answer to the question. It is humiliating to have to admit you can barely make ends meet, and equally humiliating to be seen complaining about it, even as you are taunted by the wealth that is flaunted all around you.
That the dependent ones among us are treated as lepers is understandable within a nation that worships wealth. Bigotry toward the low-income isn't against the law and so even the liberal crowd can with a clear conscience sneer and curl their lip as they contemplate the rigors of life for the working poor, that often drive the working poor toward politically incorrect or ignorant behavior.

2)Reduce the mortgage-interest deduction by a third: $650 billion .Replacing the deduction with a refundable tax credit to lower the tax bill for home owners and raise revenue for the Treasury.
3)Eliminate the special tax breaks for many industries. $300 billion.

5)Require competitive bidding on all federal contracts, and coordinate purchases between agencies: $150 billion About 1/3 of present contracts are not competative bids.

7)Eliminate subsidies for energy companies: $150 billion. .

Enjoying reading people's stories here very much.  What a nice change from the usual internet comment vitriol.  My story: Near our winter home in Florida, in a condo community, there lived a family of great horned owls.  I'd watched them for the last two years, male and female raising a family each year, gray fluffs that grew fast.  We saw them learning to fly, watched the parents bring food. Watched mostly grown son owl fly to a distant tree to sit with Dad owl.  Dad owl often sat out in the open on a light pole in late afternoon and would turn his head and look at us as we spoke to him. Sometimes he would hoot and I'd flatter myself that he was answering us.. Once, he flew within six feet by me from behind; he was being chased by mockingbirds (who relentlessly harassed him)/  Someone told me the family had been there for several years. Then this year, no owls; a big disappointment.  I miss these magnificent creatures whose lives I felt honored to peek into. I hope they found a more private place to live and are safe and happy.
